summary: The author's work was published in the journal journal Nature's "Citation_Author" magazine . The authors have collaborated on a paper on the topic of the book, "Citations" and "The Citation"
Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, Texas 79409, USA; soni@rose-hulman.edu .
Academic Editor

Flight induces physiologic alterations, including muscle and bone loss, structural changes in the eyes and brain, altered cardiovascular function, and altered cognitive function . Flight induces numerous physiologic changes, including but not limited to muscle, bone loss .
The study suggests combining -omics data from space-flown model organisms, such as C. elegans, Drosophila and rodents, with astronaut data can accelerate the discovery process .

Previous studies have demonstrated conserved gene expression changes in response to spaceflight between rodents, rodents, and humans . We hypothesized that worms would be weaker in space and aimed to directly test this on the micro-16 ISS payload .

NemaFlex mold was fabricated in SU-8 2050 negative photoresist (Microchem) on a 4″ silicon wafer as a substrate . Polydimethylsiloxane devices of 4.25 ± 0.25 mm thickness were cast using Sylgard 184 part A (base) and part B (curing agent) 10:1 by weight .

PDMS replica was treated in an air-plasma cleaner for 90s and bonded to a 2-inch glass slide . Devices were then treated with 5 wt% Pluronic F127 for 30 min to prevent bacterial build-up and reduce bubble formation during worm loading . Worms were loaded into NemaFlex-S chambers using a previously described procedure . Videos were processed

Tool 1 was used per pairwise comparison with log2 fold-change values of all genes subject to differential expression testing (i.e., the 13,897 genes that survived pre-filtering) as input in each case to determine the directional activity of the 209 defined transcriptional modules . Module descriptions potentially relevant to spaceflight and putative transcriptional regulators were subjectively assigned from

The diameters of both strains grown at ISS are significantly different compared to ground controls . The diameter of strains grown in space flight and ground control worms are different . There is no difference in the length of the worms .  The study was conducted on the ISS to measure adult worms’ muscle strength . The study used a 60-s-long video of crawling worms in NemaFlex-S chambers .
Study found gene expression in the same cultures of worms that we measured strength in, as well as two additional cultures .

Principal Component Analysis (PCA) of the most variable genes showed a distinct clustering of samples in line with experimental conditions . Spaceflight is the main driver of the bulk of gene expression changes, while the <em>dys-1 mutation has a lesser but significant effect .  4726 genes displayed significant changes in expression in response to spaceflight, with 409 uniquely up in <em>wt, 394 uniquely down in <EM>wt <em>. 394 were down, 1069 uniquely up and 1069 up in  dys-1 . 1295 were up in both strains and 819 down in  strains <a href#cells-

Venn diagram illustrates degree of commonality/uniqueness in spaceflight-upregulated genes between the two strains . Heatmap depicts representative Gene Ontology terms for common/uniquely upregulated genes up in flight .  Three modules are inhibited in response to space flight, and four modules are activated in both <em>wt and <em>.dys-1 . These observations are consistent with spaceflight being the major driver of gene expression changes .
The module analysis suggests decreased neuronal function and altered acetylcholine signal from nerve to muscle as a potential contributor to strength decline in flight .

QIAGEN Ingenuity Pathway Analysis identifies 31 drugs as being regulators of genes whose expression is either increased or decreased in flight . Current challenges include understanding how detrimental physiological changes in flight might be countered by existing medications, how medications may work differently in flight, and how to ensure our explorers receive the best possible outcome .

Response of gene expression to spaceflight has gained increased interest in the past few years . This experiment presents an example of how near-simultaneous in-flight collection of -omics alongside phenotypic measures can enable insights into the potential molecular mechanisms behind spaceflight-associated physiological deconditioning .
